article.title: Identification and characterization of a skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans suggests environmental microbes confer cuticle protection
funding: University of Portland College of Arts and Sciences Dean's Conference and Publishing Fund
Summer URS Ledell Family Research Scholarship for Science and Engineering
article.abstract: In the wild, C. elegans are emersed in environments teeming with a veritable menagerie of microorganisms. The C. elegans cuticular surface serves as a barrier and first point of contact with their microbial environments.

sections.introduction: All animals are in contact with microbial communities, termed the microbiome. Microbiomes play a significant role in shaping host physiology, adaptation, fitness, and even behavior.
sections.methods: Strains were ordered from the Caenorhabditis Genetics Center and include the following: wild-type N2; CB130 dpy-8 (e130); VC2985 dpy-10 (gk3075) II; CB6627 srf-3 (e2689) IV; CB6177 bus-8 (e2883) X.
sections.results: We sought to directly identify the existence of a resident skin microbiome on the C. elegans cuticle.
sections.discussion: Bacteriaâ€“host interactions are complex and known to impact many aspects of host biology.

article.insights_summary: We identify a skin microbiome for the well-studied nematode model and propose its value in conferring host fitness advantages in naturalized contexts.
article.acknowledgments: We would like to thank the Chalasani lab members, especially Kirthi Reddy, for their support and feedback on this nascent project.
